title: How to turn protest into powerful change - Eric Liu

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential outcomes of protest, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: It can only lead to negative change.

options.label: B
options.text: It can force out tyrants and thrust issues onto the national or global agenda.

options.label: C
options.text: It is never effective in bringing about lasting change.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only for people who are already involved in civic life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first strategy for peacefully turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Choosing a defining fight.

options.label: B
options.text: Finding an early win.

options.label: C
options.text: Expanding the frame of the possible.

options.label: D
options.text: Mobilizing voters.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "expanding the frame of the possible"?

options.label: A
options.text: It means limiting the scope of what can be achieved.

options.label: B
options.text: It means asking what if - what if it were possible to achieve a certain goal.

options.label: C
options.text: It means ignoring the constraints of conventional politics.

options.label: D
options.text: It means giving up on ambitious policy ideas.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a policy idea that might be dismissed as "not possible"?

options.label: A
options.text: A radically smaller national government.

options.label: B
options.text: A big single-payer healthcare system.

options.label: C
options.text: A way to hold corporations accountable for their misdeeds.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second strategy for peacefully turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Expanding the frame of the possible.

options.label: B
options.text: Finding an early win.

options.label: C
options.text: Choosing a defining fight.

options.label: D
options.text: Mobilizing voters.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a defining fight that has been chosen by activists, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: A $15 minimum wage in the U.S.

options.label: B
options.text: A big single-payer healthcare system.

options.label: C
options.text: A way to hold corporations accountable for their misdeeds.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the third strategy for peacefully turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Expanding the frame of the possible.

options.label: B
options.text: Choosing a defining fight.

options.label: C
options.text: Finding an early win.

options.label: D
options.text: Mobilizing voters.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an early win that helped to create momentum for a larger movement, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The Arab Spring.

options.label: B
options.text: The solidarity movement in Cold War Poland.

options.label: C
options.text: The U.S. Civil Rights Movement.

options.label: D
options.text: Indian Independence.

multiple-choice.question: What is required to achieve an early win, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Pressuring policymakers and using the media to change the narrative.

options.label: B
options.text: Making arguments in public and persuading skeptical neighbors.

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B.

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the spirit of protest, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: It is only about sudden, dramatic change.

options.label: B
options.text: It is powerful, but showing up after the protest is equally important.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only for people who are already involved in civic life.

options.label: D
options.text: It is never effective in bringing about lasting change.

title: Self-assembly: The power of organizing the unorganized - Skylar Tibbits

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when unordered parts come together in an organized structure on their own?

options.label: A
options.text: Self destruction

options.label: B
options.text: Self assembly

options.label: C
options.text: Self disassembly

options.label: D
options.text: Self creation

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how proteins self assemble in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: By forming a linear chain

options.label: B
options.text: By folding into a 3-D structure due to amino acid interactions

options.label: C
options.text: By replicating DNA

options.label: D
options.text: By interacting with RNA

multiple-choice.question: What is an analogy for how viruses self assemble?

options.label: A
options.text: A bicycle chain

options.label: B
options.text: A soccer ball

options.label: C
options.text: A snowflake

options.label: D
options.text: A magnet

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential application of self assembly in technology?

options.label: A
options.text: Making precise spheres through traditional means

options.label: B
options.text: Creating molecular microchips for computers

options.label: C
options.text: Building 3-D structures with DNA

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of using self assembly in design and engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced reliance on fossil fuels

options.label: B
options.text: Increased human error

options.label: C
options.text: More complex technologies

options.label: D
options.text: Less adaptive technologies

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how self assembly can be used to make 3-D structures with DNA?

options.label: A
options.text: To create capsules that deliver drugs inside the body

options.label: B
options.text: To build precise spheres

options.label: C
options.text: To form linear chains

options.label: D
options.text: To replicate DNA

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential future application of self assembly in construction?

options.label: A
options.text: Building structures that cannot adapt to the environment

options.label: B
options.text: Creating materials that cannot repair themselves

options.label: C
options.text: Building structures that can adapt to the environment and repair themselves

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is an analogy for how our bodies are built and how our immune system works?

options.label: A
options.text: A factory and copy machine

options.label: B
options.text: A transformer and the Sandman

options.label: C
options.text: A bicycle chain and a snowflake

options.label: D
options.text: A soccer ball and a magnet

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of using self assembly in design and engineering for the environment?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased reliance on fossil fuels

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced reliance on fossil fuels

options.label: C
options.text: No impact on the environment

options.label: D
options.text: Increased pollution

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential future application of self assembly in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Building structures that cannot adapt to dynamic loading

options.label: B
options.text: Creating materials that cannot repair themselves

options.label: C
options.text: Building structures that can adapt to the environment and repair themselves

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of cognitive diversity in a team when it comes to tasks like problem-solving and coming up with creative ideas?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces the number of ideas generated.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the number of ideas generated.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on the number of ideas generated.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes it more difficult to come up with ideas.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a group of people with the same perspective work together to come up with ideas?

options.label: A
options.text: They generate a large number of unique ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: They generate a small number of unique ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: They generate the same number of ideas as a group with diverse perspectives.

options.label: D
options.text: They generate no ideas.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why people are attracted to others who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a conscious decision to surround themselves with like-minded individuals.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a psychological phenomenon that makes people feel smarter.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a necessary step in solving complex problems.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a way to validate their world view.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a group of people with the same perspective work together to solve a complex problem?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident in their solution.

options.label: B
options.text: They generate a large number of unique solutions.

options.label: C
options.text: They become more confident in their solution, but may be gravely mistaken.

options.label: D
options.text: They become less confident in their solution.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the key feature of competitive advantage for the next 50 years?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive diversity.

options.label: B
options.text: Homogeneous thinking.

options.label: C
options.text: Complex problem-solving.

options.label: D
options.text: Economic forecasting.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept discussed in the transcript that highlights the importance of cognitive diversity?

options.label: A
options.text: The power of cognitive diversity.

options.label: B
options.text: The tragedy of cognitive diversity.

options.label: C
options.text: The concept of collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of economic forecasting.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it wrong to believe that working with people who think like you is the best approach?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's a conscious decision to surround yourself with like-minded individuals.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's a necessary step in solving complex problems.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's a spectacularly wrong logic.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's a way to validate your world view.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of cognitive diversity in a team when it comes to complex problem-solving?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces the number of solutions generated.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the number of solutions generated.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on the number of solutions generated.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes it more difficult to come up with solutions.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why people are attracted to others who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a conscious decision to surround themselves with like-minded individuals.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a psychological phenomenon that makes people feel smarter.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a necessary step in solving complex problems.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a way to validate their world view.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point made in the transcript about the importance of cognitive diversity?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a necessary step in solving complex problems.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a way to validate your world view.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a key feature of competitive advantage for the next 50 years.

options.label: D
